text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with the Cornish pasty that's right
this amazing meat pie hell's from
Cornwall England which reminds me why is
this not called Cornwallis pasty I'm
gonna need an explanation for that but
regardless this is an incredibly
versatile crust and a technique that any
good cook should know especially ones
partial to meat pies so let's go ahead
and get started with the dough and for
that we're gonna need some bread flour
you can use all-purpose although if you
can try to use bread flour it does work
a little better here we're also going to
throw in some salts and then of course
we're going to need some fat so I'm
going to toss in some lard and I know I
know everybody's health-conscious these
days and watching their diets but don't
worry we're also going to add butter at
this point we're going to take our wire
pastry blender also known as a pastry
cutter and work that fat into the flour
and yes you can do this with your
fingertips but this tool does make life
a little easier so we're gonna work that
mixture with our pastry cutter until we
basically have like a coarse crumbly
mixture and when you've gone far enough
it should look something like this
so that looks good and then it's time
for the last ingredient so we'll make a
little well in the middle and we'll pour
in some ice water and then the plan here
is we're going to mix this with a fork
until it just starts to come together
and then we'll switch and finish it by
hand all right so give that a mix with
your fork until it gets annoying to stir
then clean off the fork and switch to
your hands and as soon as it feels like
you can start wetting that into a ball
of dough we're going to transfer that to
our work surface and this is where
things are going to get a little weird
so far this has basically been standard
pie crust making procedure and if we
were making pie at this point we would
gently shape this into a ball of dough
without overworking it but we're not
doing pie crust okay for this pasty
crust we're actually going to knead this
for a couple minutes I know it sounds
crazy
all right the Cornish pasty is minor
food so think of this crust is more like
an edible lunchbox that protected their
meat and vegetables so that's why we
want to give this a couple minutes of
kneading so we end up with a crust
that's a little more sturdy and by the
way sturdy does not mean tough as you'll
see this is not a tough crust at all but
it does need to stand up to that filling
and be fairly durable in fact the old
joke is a proper Cornish pasty should
survive a fall down a mineshaft without
breaking now unfortunately I can't test
mine I've been asked to stop visiting
the local mine shafts but the point is
you pie makers do not be concerned about
this step it is very necessary ok and
dirty
this couple minutes of kneading the heat
from your fingers is going to melt some
of that lard which is going to
incorporate into the dough and after
working it for about two minutes you
should have something that looks pretty
smooth so I'm going to stop right here
that's looking very good and at this
point we're going to go ahead and wrap
that in plastic and chill thoroughly
before working with this alright at
least a few hours or overnight and of
course while you're waiting for your
dough to chill that's the perfect time
to make your filling which by the way I
was going to do is a separate video but
it's so simple I decide to shoehorn it
in here and then I'll fill in the blanks
on the blog post but I'm going to go
with a very traditional filling of steak
that's some dice skirt steak some onion
some potato and some turnip and besides
seasoning this with some salt freshly
ground black pepper and cayenne that's
it so an extremely simple filling and
please take note everything's raw that's
one of the secrets to this dish and
that's going to be enough filling for
four very nicely sized pasties okay so
our filling is done our dough is chilled
and it's time for final production so
we're going to go ahead and take our
thoroughly chilled dough cut it into
four equal pieces and then we'll take
one of those pieces and shape it with
our hands into something sort of round
as you'll see it doesn't have to be
perfect there is extra dough here to
work with and using just enough flour so
it doesn't stick we're going to roll
that out to about eight inches wide
about an eighth of an inch thick maybe
just a hair thicker than an eighth of an
inch so that's what I did here so that
looks good if you have any excess flour
just brush it off and then before we
fill this we're going to have to do one
very important step the old egg wash so
we're going to take one egg that's been
beaten with one teaspoon of water and
we're going to paint that all over the
surface no not just where it seals do
the whole thing that way you're covered
literally and once that set let's go
ahead and pile on our filling and we
want to be very generous here if you're
not nervous about it being overstuffed
you're not putting it enough in so let's
pile that up and as you can see it's
off-center because we need to fold over
this dough and then before we fold this
we want to top it with a couple slices
of butter a very key step but easy to
forget so please take note both mental
and written and at that point we can
fold over the dough and press it all the
way around with our fingers to seal as
long as you're not pressing filling
exactly where it's going to seal your
okay so just go around you should have
plenty of extra dough to work with and
then once that's pressed firmly we're
going to go ahead and cut off the excess
so I'm gonna take a little spin on the
pizza cutter and go around with that of
course a knife will work but that's not
how I roll okay so we're going to remove
that excess dough and then we'll
transfer that onto our lined baking

usually do when you see me make pie but
I'm sorry I prefer the fork crimp
because it gives you a thinner crisper

you're nasty
of your Cornish pasty so we're gonna let
you decide like I said I prefer the fork
but anyway once those are crimped we're
going to go ahead and take the fork and
stick it right down in the top so that
the steam has somewhere to escape while
these are baking and yes usually a
little bit of juice will run out of that
and kind of caramelize onto your pan
that's okay
better that than the bottom or the side
splitting and at this point these are

so let's make sure our oven is preheated
to 350 and we'll take the rest of our
egg wash and paint these thoroughly
all right Cornish Pasties are not
supposed to have tan lines so make sure
you cover the entire surface I hate it
when part of a pastry doesn't have egg
wash on it
that's one of my roughly 375 culinary
pet peeves and once those are egg washed
we're going to pop those into the center
of a 350 degree oven for about an hour
or until they look like this they should
be beautifully golden there should be
steam and juices escaping from the holes
on the top and depending on your filling
should smell amazing and technically you
can eat these any time but they're
probably way too hot right now so I'm
gonna pop those on a rack to cool for at
least five or ten minutes I know I hate
to wait
but what I hate more are third-degree
burns on the roof of my mouth so I let

point your Cornish pasty is done by the
way this thing is the original actually
I shouldn't give the brand name this

first I got to get rid of this time it
was not used in the recipe why did I

mistake never do that but anyway let me
cut into this and go in for the full

is the combination between that crisp
flaky outer crust and the moist tender
inner crust that's basically been
steamed with all those delicious meat
and vegetable juices just a perfect
combination of tastes and textures and
like I said earlier while this is
sturdier from the kneading it is not
tough at all it is still very tender
very light and just a fantastic bite of
food and then before we sign off one
this piece of footage let's say for the
sake of argument you can't wait for your
pie to cool down no problem just cut it
in half and pour cold cream in it before
you bite it not only will that prevent
you from burning your mouth it's cream
it's going to make everything even
richer and more delicious so just a
little extra trick I learned from my
friends in Cornwall but anyway whether
you eat them straight out of the oven or
let them cool down a little bit I really
hope you give these Cornish Pasties a
